message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Beyond Western, Educated, Industrial, Rich, and Democratic (WEIRD) Psychology: Measuring and Mapping Scales of Cultural and Psychological Distance
Paper Abstract: In this article, we present a tool and a method for measuring the psychological and cultural distance between societies and creating a distance scale with any population as the point of comparison. Because psychological data are dominated by samples drawn from Western, educated, industrialized, rich, and democratic (WEIRD) nations, and overwhelmingly, the United States, we focused on distance from the United States. We also present distance from China, the country with the largest population and second largest economy, which is a common cultural comparison. We applied the fixation index ( F ST ), a meaningful statistic in evolutionary theory, to the World Values Survey of cultural beliefs and behaviors. As the extreme WEIRDness of the literature begins to dissolve, our tool will become more useful for designing, planning, and justifying a wide range of comparative psychological projects. Our code and accompanying online application allow for comparisons between any two countries. Analyses of regional diversity reveal the relative homogeneity of the United States. Cultural distance predicts various psychological outcomes.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the fixation index in evolutionary biology:

## Definition and Basics

The fixation index (FST) is a measure of population differentiation due to genetic structure.(no content)Developed as a special case of Wright's F-statistics, it is one of the most commonly used statistics in population genetics.

## Values and Interpretation

Its values range from 0 to 1, with 0 being no differentiation and 1 being complete differentiation. More specifically, a zero value implies complete panmixia; that is, that the two populations are interbreeding freely.(no content)A value of one implies that all genetic variation is explained by the population structure, and that the two populations do not share any genetic diversity.

## Data and Applications

It is frequently estimated from genetic polymorphism data, such as single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) or microsatellites.(no content)For idealized models such as Wright's finite island model, FST can be used to estimate migration rates.(no content)This comparison of genetic variability within and between populations is frequently used in applied population genetics.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about WEIRD psychology:

## Definition and Origin

WEIRD is a backronym that stands for "Western, Educated, Industrialized, Rich, and Democratic", and which summarizes the background of most participants in psychological research.(no content)The most commonly used participants in psychological and behavioral research are not only a single type of population within a global spectrum, but are particularly psychologically peculiar.

## Key Research and Critique

The WEIRDest People in the World: How the West Became Psychologically Peculiar and Particularly Prosperous is a 2020 book by Harvard University professor Joseph Henrich that aims to explain history and psychological variation using approaches from cultural evolution and evolutionary psychology.(no content)Henrich argues that a series of Catholic Church edicts on marriage that began in the 4th century undermined the foundations of kin-based society and created the more analytical, individualistic thinking prevalent in western societies.

## Significance in Psychology

The WEIRD concept highlights an important methodological issue in psychological research: There has been repeated failure to replicate Western psychology laboratory findings in non-Western settings. Therefore, a major goal of cultural psychology is to have many and varied cultures contribute to basic psychological theories in order to correct these theories so that they become more relevant to the predictions, descriptions, and explanations of all human behaviors, not just Western ones.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "World Values Survey"

Links: [{"title":"World Values Survey - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Values_Survey"},{"title":"Inglehart–Welzel cultural map of the world - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inglehart–Welzel_cultural_map_of_the_world"},{"title":"Talk:World Values Survey - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:World_Values_Survey"},{"title":"Postmaterialism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postmaterialism"},{"title":"World Happiness Report - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Happiness_Index"},{"title":"Freedom Rising - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedom_Rising"},{"title":"Well-being contributing factors - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Well-being_-_Contributing_factors_and_research_findings"},{"title":"New Zealand Attitudes and Values Study - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand_Attitudes_and_Values_Study"},{"title":"Self-expression values - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-expression_Values"},{"title":"Happy Planet Index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Happy_Planet_Index"}]

## World Values Survey

The World Values Survey (WVS) is a global research project that explores people's values and beliefs, how they change over time, and what social and political impact they have.(no content)Since 1981 a worldwide network of social scientists have conducted representative national surveys as part of WVS.

### Origins and Development

The World Values Surveys were designed to test the hypothesis that economic and technological changes are transforming the basic values and motivations of the publics of industrialized societies. The surveys build on the European Values Study (EVS) first carried out in 1981.(no content)Ronald Inglehart of the University of Michigan played a leading role in extending these surveys to be carried out in countries around the world.

### Key Dimensions and Frameworks

Analysis of the World Values Survey data by Inglehart and Welzel asserts that there are two major dimensions of cross-cultural variation in the world: x-axis: Survival values versus self-expression values · y-axis: Traditional values versus secular–rational values. This framework is visualized in the Inglehart–Welzel Cultural Map, which is updated regularly with new WVS data.

### Applications and Uses

World Values Survey data is used by the United Nation Development Programme in order to calculate the gender social norms index. The index measures attitudes toward gender equality worldwide and was introduced in the Human Development Report starting from 2019. Additionally, data used to rank countries in some World Happiness Report reports is drawn from the World Values Survey.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of cultural distance and cross-cultural concepts:

## Cross-Cultural Overview

Cross-culturalism is concerned with exchange beyond the boundaries of the nation or cultural group, distinguishing it from multiculturalism, which deals with diversity within a single nation.

## Cultural Distance Frameworks

Hofstede's cultural dimensions theory is a framework for cross-cultural psychology that shows the effects of a society's culture on the values of its members, and how these values relate to behavior. This initial analysis identified systematic differences in national cultures on four primary dimensions: power distance (PDI), individualism (IDV), uncertainty avoidance (UAI) and masculinity (MAS).

## Cross-Cultural Communication

Cross-cultural communication is a field of study investigating how people from differing cultural backgrounds communicate, in similar and different ways among themselves, and how they endeavor to communicate across cultures. Cross-cultural communication endeavors to bring together the relatively unrelated fields of cultural anthropology with established areas of communication, involves understanding the ways in which culturally distinct individuals communicate with each other, and aims to produce guidelines with which people from different cultures can better communicate with each other.

## Cross-Cultural Psychology

Cross-cultural psychology is the scientific study of human behavior and mental processes, including both their variability and invariance, under diverse cultural conditions.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Psychological distance psychology"

Links: [{"title":"Psychological distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychological_distance"},{"title":"Distancing (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distancing_(psychology)"},{"title":"Construal level theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Construal_level_theory"},{"title":"Psychic distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychic_distance"},{"title":"Social distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_distance"},{"title":"Distancing language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distancing_language"},{"title":"Emotional detachment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotional_detachment"},{"title":"Similarity (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mental_distance"},{"title":"Social distance corollary - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_distance_corollary"},{"title":"Distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distance"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of psychological distance in psychology:

## Definition

The relationship between someone and an event, in regard to psychological distance, is such that the greater the distance between the self and an event, the lower the mental perception of importance is for the person.(no content)Psychological distance is fundamentally egocentric, with the anchor point being the self in the present, and the different interactions of the self with an object or event correlating to different levels of distance.

## Key Theory: Construal Level Theory

Construal level theory (CLT) is a theory in social psychology that describes the relationbetween psychological distance and the extent to which people's thinking (e.g., about objects and events) is abstract or concrete.(no content)The core idea of CLT is that the more distant an object is from the individual, the more abstract it will be thought of, while the closer the object is, the more concretely it will be thought of.

## Dimensions of Psychological Distance

In CLT, psychological distance is defined on several dimensions—temporal, spatial, social and hypothetical distance being considered most important, though there is some debate among social psychologists about further dimensions like informational, experiential or affective distance.

## Effects on Behavior and Perception

This psychological distance causes behavioral differences, or non-existence of certain behaviors or attitudes all together, that alter one's response to an event by changing the perception of its importance in one's mind.(no content)Several studies have concluded that public concern regarding climate change and environmental issues decreases as one's perceived psychological distance from the issue increases.

In CLT, psychological distance is defined on several dimensions—temporal, spatial, social and hypothetical distance being considered most important, though there is some debate among social psychologists about further dimensions like informational, experiential or affective distance.

## Effects on Behavior and Perception

This psychological distance causes behavioral differences, or non-existence of certain behaviors or attitudes all together, that alter one's response to an event by changing the perception of its importance in one's mind.(no content)Several studies have concluded that public concern regarding climate change and environmental issues decreases as one's perceived psychological distance from the issue increases.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of psychological distance in psychology:

## Definition

The relationship between someone and an event, in regard to psychological distance, is such that the greater the distance between the self and an event, the lower the mental perception of importance is for the person.(no content)Psychological distance is fundamentally egocentric, with the anchor point being the self in the present, and the different interactions of the self with an object or event correlating to different levels of distance.

## Key Theory: Construal Level Theory

Construal level theory (CLT) is a theory in social psychology that describes the relationbetween psychological distance and the extent to which people's thinking (e.g., about objects and events) is abstract or concrete.(no content)The core idea of CLT is that the more distant an object is from the individual, the more abstract it will be thought of, while the closer the object is, the more concretely it will be thought of.

## Dimensions of Psychological Distance

In CLT, psychological distance is defined on several dimensions—temporal, spatial, social and hypothetical distance being considered most important, though there is some debate among social psychologists about further dimensions like informational, experiential or affective distance.

## Effects on Behavior and Perception

This psychological distance causes behavioral differences, or non-existence of certain behaviors or attitudes all together, that alter one's response to an event by changing the perception of its importance in one's mind.(no content)Several studies have concluded that public concern regarding climate change and environmental issues decreases as one's perceived psychological distance from the issue increases.
